The topic =
of cutting test inscriptions on swords came up yesterday as a few of us gat=
hered here for a day of swords. One tested sword we looked at was a Mino Ka=
nemichi, the sue-koto smith and father of the famous Mishina den family of =
smiths in early shin-to times. The "test" is carved into the nakago -- not =
kinzogan -- and is unsigned and undated. Examining the "age" of the test in=
scription v/s Kanemichi's mei, they appear to be of the same age. This brou=
ght out a number of questions:The earliest known "dated" cutting test?Koto =
era test inscriptions; has anyone read about when "testing" began to be ins=
cribed on nakago?Is it possible that initially, test inscriptions were cut =
into the nakago informally (undated, simple statement), then became more fo=
rmal (gold inlaid, tester noted and test dated) and later in shinshinto tim=
es, again became simply carved statements but perhaps more complete -- date=
d, at least? We see some kinzogan "test inscriptions" -- ones I call "unoff=
icial" because there is not date or tester name -- possibly true cutting te=
sts not but simply not performed by one of the more known "tester families.=
" Is this correct thinking? To my limited knowledge, based one what is typi=
cally found in our more common reference books, kinzogan inscriptions were =
a mid/late shin-to era thing. Then you read about the shinshin-to inscripti=
ons that are more commonly found not of kinzogan, but simply "cut" into the=
 nakago. Talking about this it seems logical that perhaps when tests were i=
nitially "put on a nakago" that they were simply "carved statements" attest=
ing to the sword's cutting ability. Then came the fad of kinzogan tests and=
 families doing this task professionally. For some reason shinshin-to tests=
 seem to typically be without kinzogan, but still with "details" such as da=
te and tester. The idea of "transition" test inscriptions came up, perhaps =
as on the Kanemichi daito -- simple "this cut through..." -- which evolved =
into formal kinzogan tests inscriptions. If later fad ended up as in shinsh=
in-to times -- inscripted in detail but not kinzogan. (Then of course the i=
dea of "unoffical" tests mentioned earlier.) Just passing these ideas out t=
o the groups. I've only seen one publication of testing -- a two-volume set=
; name escapes me -- but it would seem "somebody" would had researched this=
 topic in great depth somewhere along the way. Comments????RonSTL[Non-text =
portions of this message have been removed]
